qas.question: West Buddhism is often seen as exotic and what?
New forms of Buddhism are created because of what reason?

context: Formal membership varies between communities, but basic lay adherence is often defined in terms of a traditional formula in which the practitioner takes refuge in The Three Jewels: the Buddha, the Dharma (<a0_0>the teachings of the Buddha<a0_0/>), and the Sangha (<a1_0>the Buddhist community<a1_0/>). At the present time, the teachings of all three branches of Buddhism have spread throughout the world, and Buddhist texts are increasingly translated into local languages. While in the West Buddhism is often seen as exotic and <a2_0>progressive<a2_0/>, in the East it is regarded as familiar and traditional. Buddhists in Asia are frequently well organized and well funded. In countries such as Cambodia and Bhutan, it is recognized as the state religion and receives government support. <a3_0>Modern influences<a3_0/> increasingly lead to new forms of Buddhism that significantly depart from traditional beliefs and practices.
